page.title: 04ASHDOWN FOREST PLANT LIFE
page.content: The uncultivated land is covered by Grass, Heather (3 varieties) and Bracken, which predominates and increases after fires. Trees grow in clumps or coppices and are principally Pine, Silver Birch and Rowans with a few Oaks and Sweet Chestnuts. There are both Dwarf and European Gorse. In the wet heathland Rushes, Bog Asphodel and several varieties of Sphagnum Moss flourish. Wild flowers are not prolific but many kinds can be seen, including Tormentil, Hawkbit, Devil's Bit, Scabious, Heath Spotted Orchids and Harebells by the road verges. Cotton Grass, Mountain Fern Bilberries, Blackberries, Gawltheria, Shallon and Honeysuckle are common. While access to the Forest is free, the Forest Code is to admire and photograph but never to dig up plants and to be sure not to damage trees.
